CLEVELAND DIVISION OF WATER
BALDWIN WATER TREATMENT PLANT
2004 RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Cleveland Division of Water (CWD) is a municipal water utility that provides approximately 1.5 million people throughout the greater Cleveland area, producing an average of 240 million gallons per day of high-quality, safe drinking water.  CWD?s senior management and its employees undertake a daily mission to provide a reliable supply of high-quality, safe drinking water and efficient cost-effective services consistent with sound environmental and safety practices.  In order to do so, chlorine an extremely hazardous chemical is used daily to disinfect the drinking water.   However, through training and standard operating procedures the employees of CWD demonstrate extreme conscientiousness in handling the chlorine. They are dedicated to preventing accidents, and if necessary, responding to accidental chlorine releases.

The Facility & The Regulated Substances Handled

The Baldwin Water Treatment Plant is one of four CWD water treatment plants and produces approximately 19.7 billion gallons of drinking water each year.  Approximately 1,500 - 2,000 pounds of chlorine is used each day at the plant as a part of the treatment process.  Chlorine is supplied to the water treatment plant as a toxic gas, liquefied under pressure in one-ton steel containers.  The facility can currently store a maximum of 30 one-ton containers, approximately 60,000 pounds on-site at any one time. To reduce accidental releases, no more than 24,000 pounds is shipped at one time. 

Both the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) lists chlorine as an extremely hazardous chemical, as exposure to chlorine can result in serious health effects.  The primary health concern from exposure to chlorine is its toxic effect when inhaled.  At the Baldwin facility, the chlorination system is a closed system that converts the liquid chlorine into chlorine gas and

then injects the gas into water to form chlorine solution.  The chlorine solution can then be added into raw water before it enters the water treatment process.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

CWD has long understood the hazards of handling chlorine, which if not handled properly, can pose a risk to employees, the environment, and the surrounding community. With the inception of OSHA Process Safety requirements, CWD has worked hard at building what we call a "Layers of Protection" approach to safety.  CWD has developed and implemented detailed SOPs for the safe operation of the Chlorination System, a comprehensive maintenance program for inspecting, testing, repairing, and replacing chlorine equipment including detection systems, alarms, and emergency equipment.  Additional practices and policies include personnel protection equipment (PPE), employee training, incident reporting and investigation procedures, safe work practices such as hot work permits and lockout/tagout procedures, and a visitor policy to control access to the plant especially to areas where chlorine is stored and/or used.  These programs are in place to reduce the likelihood of an accidental chlorine release. 

In addition to CWD's well-maintained chlorine equipment and well-trained employees, CWD's management is committed to minimizing the potential for accidental chlorine releases and minimizing the effects of a release if one were to occur.  CWD routinely re-evaluates and updates it's policies, programs, and procedures to ensure that we are providing the safest environment possible for our employees, the community, and the environment. 


Five-year Accident History

The Baldwin Water Treatment Plant has used chlorine to disinfect drinking water for more than 80 years.  In the last five years, the Baldwin facility had two RMP reportable accidental releases; the largest was 40 pounds.  The incident occurred on May 28, 2004.  Chlorine gas was released while an employee was in the p

rocess of connecting a new one-ton cylinder to the chlorination system and was unable to tighten the valve securely.  A Chlorine Institute Emergency ?B? kit was used to contain the leak.  

Emergency Response Program

The Baldwin Water Treatment Plant has a chlorine-specific Emergency Response Plan which identifies procedures for recognizing emergencies, securing incident areas, and responding to releases and leaks, and emergency evacuation procedures, routes, and safe assembly points.  There are also procedures for accounting for all personnel following an evacuation, emergency first aid for exposure to chlorine, notifying local emergency response agencies and the public, and the duties and responsibilities of facility personnel currently assigned as members of the emergency response team.

All of the water treatment plant operators are properly trained to respond to and mitigate chlorine incidents that might potentially occur at the plant.  They are trained in hazardous operations response and in the use of Chlorine Institute Emergency B-Kits for one-ton containers.  In addition, the facility is staffed with operators 24 hours a day.  CWD also coordinates its Emergency Response Plan with the Cleveland Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) Team and the Cuyahoga County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).  In conjunction with the establishment of an RMP Program, CWD has established a program to conduct annual chlorine drills with Cleveland HAZMAT in preparation for a potential response to an accidental release.

Planned Changes to Improve Employee and Environmental Safety

CWD is always looking for ways to reduce employee and community risk and improve safety.  The Baldwin Water Treatment Plant is currently undergoing major renovation activities as part of CWD?s Plant Enhancement Program to further reduce these risks and is converting from the use of chlorine to sodium hypochlorite as our primary disinfectant.
